title: Build Your OT Toolbox: It's Dangerous to Go Alone, So Take These Tools
description: OT/ICS defense is reliant on how good your tool stack is. We've compiled a list of helpful tools for your OT toolbox.

title: C.J. Stroud must clean up play to not waste Texans' historic defense
description: The Houston Texans' defense dominated the Pittsburgh Steelers, but C.J. Stroud's sloppiness (three turnovers) was cause for concern.
fullText:
PITTSBURGH ‚Äî Stating the obvious here, the Houston Texans‚Äô defense is championship caliber ‚Äì to the point they may carry the entire roster to northern California themselves within the next month.

That also means the pressure is on quarterback C.J. Stroud and the other side of the ball, because not supporting what has developed into one of the most simultaneously suffocating and crushing units in recent memory would be to waste a potentially deep postseason run in a weaker AFC field.

DeMeco Ryans‚Äô unit scored twice in Houston‚Äôs 30-6 rout of the Pittsburgh Steelers in the wild-card round Monday, Jan. 13, at Acrisure Stadium. The concerning part is that Stroud‚Äôs carelessness with the football, which resulted in two fumbles lost (five fumbles total and several issues with the snap) and a red-zone interception, kept the Steelers in the game for more than three quarters despite the Texans‚Äô defense ultimately surrendering the fewest points and yards in team postseason history.

"Bad plays happen, turnovers happen in a game," Ryans said. "We bounced back and didn‚Äôt let that affect us the rest of the game."

The defense was credited with 12 hits against Steelers quarterback Aaron Rodgers, whom they sacked four times.

Ryans liked that the offense finished the game strong regardless of prior mistakes. Stroud still displayed his flashes of greatness. There was the first third-down throw of the game to Christian Kirk for 36 yards and a third-and-15 completion to Kirk for 46 yards on the final play of the third quarter, which flipped the field and led to a Ka'imi Fairbairn field goal that made it 10-6.

"He didn‚Äôt waver," Ryans said of Stroud. "You can easily go in the tank, but he didn‚Äôt waver. That‚Äôs who he is. He is a resilient young man who‚Äôs able to bounce back. Anybody can go in the tank (after) you drop the ball a few times. You keep battling. Like, the game isn‚Äôt over."

In Ryans‚Äô third season (and Stroud‚Äôs), the Texans are 3-0 in wild-card games. They are the second head coach-quarterback duo since 1950 to make it to the divisional round in each of their first three seasons in the NFL. They will try to avoid going 0-3 in that round Sunday on the road against the New England Patriots (3 p.m. ET, ESPN/ABC).

"It was an outstanding defensive performance, one of the best that I‚Äôve seen versus a really talented offense, talented quarterback who has played at a high level for a long time," Ryans said of facing Rodgers. "So, I‚Äôm proud of our defensive performance. I think this is the best performance we‚Äôve had in our team history, so I‚Äôm proud of our guys for that."

The dam eventually broke with less than 12 minutes in the fourth quarter when Rodgers dropped back and Will Anderson Jr. curled around the edge to his blind side. The 2023 No. 3 overall pick dislodged the pigskin while demolishing Rodgers, and Sheldon Rankins picked it up and ran 33 yards for a touchdown to make it 17-6. Calen Bullock intercepted Rodgers with the game already out of reach but housed it 50 yards to make it 30-6.

"I think our defense has played like this all year," Stroud said. "They've held us up. I think this is one of the best performances I've ever seen. It's crazy to think the last three wild-card games I've played in they've always had a pick six and some type of two-turnover game. When you have a defense like that it's really, really encouraging."

The offensive line, a sore spot for the past two seasons that has clouded Stroud‚Äôs development, held up against a Steelers‚Äô front that could have been more disruptive. Instead, the blockers gave Stroud plenty of time and were difference-makers in the run game. Rookie Woody Marks went for a season-high 112 rushing yards on 19 attempts, while Nick Chubb ran hard for 48 yards on 10 carries. Stroud completed 21 of 32 passes for 250 passing yards, and six different receivers caught at least two passes, with Kirk leading the way (8 catches, 144 yards, 1 touchdown). Nico Collins‚Äô concussion will be something to monitor leading into the matchup against New England.

The line was instrumental in sustaining two lengthy touchdown drives. The first was a 14-play, 92-yard sequence in which the Texans rushed seven times for 55 yards and took 7:01 off the clock. Marks‚Äô 13-yard touchdown with 3:43 left in the fourth capped a five-minute, 51-second possession. Stroud‚Äôs efficiency on third down ‚Äì the Texans started the game 7-for-9 ‚Äì was another positive. Stroud said every teammate has a high standard of accountability.

"It's not just on C.J., not just on me," Stroud said. "I've been on teams like that, where there is a lot of the pressure (on me). Everybody is, ‚ÄòI could have done this better,‚Äô I could have done that better.‚Äô I think it does start with me. I got to take care of the football. Other than that, I thought I played a good game."

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: C.J. Stroud must play cleaner for sake of Texans' dominant defense

title: Pentagon is embracing Grok AI chatbot as it draws global outcry
description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth says Elon Musk‚Äôs artificial intelligence chatbot Grok will join Google‚Äôs AI engine inside the Pentagon network.
fullText:
WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said Monday that Elon Musk‚Äôs artificial intelligence chatbot Grok will join Google‚Äôs generative AI engine in operating inside the Pentagon network, as part of a broader push to feed as much of the military‚Äôs data as possible into the developing technology.

‚ÄúVery soon we will have the world‚Äôs leading AI models on every unclassified and classified network throughout our department,‚Äù Hegseth said in a speech at Musk‚Äôs space flight company, SpaceX, in South Texas.

The announcement comes just days after Grok ‚Äî which is embedded into X, the social media network owned by Musk ‚Äî drew global outcry and scrutiny for generating highly sexualized deepfake images of people without their consent.

Malaysia and Indonesia have blocked Grok, while the U.K.‚Äôs independent online safety watchdog announced an investigation Monday. Grok has limited image generation and editing to paying users.

Hegseth said Grok will go live inside the Defense Department later this month and announced that he would ‚Äúmake all appropriate data‚Äù from the military‚Äôs IT systems available for ‚ÄúAI exploitation.‚Äù He also said data from intelligence databases would be fed into AI systems.

Hegseth‚Äôs aggressive push to embrace the still-developing technology stands in contrast to the Biden administration, which, while pushing federal agencies to come up with policies and uses for AI, was also wary of misuse. Officials said rules were needed to ensure that the technology, which could be harnessed for mass surveillance, cyberattacks or even lethal autonomous devices, was being used responsibly.

The Biden administration enacted a framework in late 2024 that directed national security agencies to expand their use of the most advanced AI systems but prohibited certain uses, such as applications that would violate constitutionally protected civil rights or any system that would automate the deployment of nuclear weapons. It is unclear if those prohibitions are still in place under the Trump administration.

During his speech, Hegseth spoke of the need to streamline and speed up technological innovations within the military, saying, ‚ÄúWe need innovation to come from anywhere and evolve with speed and purpose.‚Äù

He noted that the Pentagon possesses ‚Äúcombat-proven operational data from two decades of military and intelligence operations.‚Äù

‚ÄúAI is only as good as the data that it receives, and we‚Äôre going to make sure that it‚Äôs there,‚Äù Hegseth said.

The defense secretary said he wants AI systems within the Pentagon to be responsible, though he went on to say he was shrugging off any AI models ‚Äúthat won‚Äôt allow you to fight wars.‚Äù

Hegseth said his vision for military AI systems means that they operate ‚Äúwithout ideological constraints that limit lawful military applications,‚Äù before adding that the Pentagon‚Äôs ‚ÄúAI will not be woke.‚Äù

Musk developed and pitched Grok as an alternative to what he called ‚Äúwoke AI‚Äù interactions from rival chatbots like Google‚Äôs Gemini or OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT. In July, Grok also caused controversy after it appeared to make antisemitic comments that praised Adolf Hitler and shared several antisemitic posts.

The Pentagon did not immediately respond to questions about the issues with Grok.

title: Aaron Rodgers calls out 'Twitter experts' during passionate defense of Steelers coach Mike Tomlin
description: With both of their futures up in the air, Aaron Rodgers had a lot to say about Mike Tomlin's job security on Monday night.
fullText:
Aaron Rodgers calls out 'Twitter experts' during passionate defense of Steelers coach Mike Tomlin originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Arguably two most important positions in football are up in the air for the Pittsburgh Steelers.

Not only could quarterback Aaron Rodgers be heading for retirement this offseason, leaving the Steelers without a plan at the position, but head coach Mike Tomlin has been speculated as a candidate to part ways with the team after nearly two decades. After Monday's 30-6 playoff loss to the Houston Texans, the next questions for Pittsburgh revolve around Rodgers and Tomlin.

In Rodgers' opinion, however, there should be no questions over Tomlin's job security with the Steelers. The veteran quarterback spoke at-length in his postgame press conference on Monday about how silly he found it that Tomlin, one of the best coaches in NFL history, would be on the "hot seat."

Here's what Rodgers had to say about Mike Tomlin potentially being fired by the Steelers.

What Aaron Rodgers said about potential NFL retirement

3 reasons why Aaron Rodgers should come back for 2026 season

Rodgers is typically a hot commodity at his press conferences, and for many reasons, his postgame presser after Monday's playoff loss may have been his most important of the 2025 season. The question many fans wanted to know, of course, was if he'd be returning to the NFL in 2026.

Rodgers, however, said "I'm not gonna talk about that."

"I'm not going to make any emotional decisions," Rodgers said. "I'm disappointed. It was such a fun year. Lot of adversity, but a lot of fun."

"I'm not going to make any emotional decisions."

‚ÄìAaron Rodgers when asked about his future. pic.twitter.com/3gU7HNNVC1

‚Äî ESPN (@espn) January 13, 2026

While Rodgers didn't have a lot to say about his own future, he did have a lot to say about Mike Tomlin's future in Pittsburgh.

MORE: Will Aaron Rodgers retire?

Postgame on Monday, Rodgers was asked about Tomlin, who hasn't led the Steelers to a playoff win since 2016 despite six postseason trips since then. Despite rumors that Pittsburgh could choose to part ways with its longtime coach, Rodgers wasn't buying it.

In a lengthy rant about how opinions from media and "Twitter experts" have affected the coach's job security, Rodgers said he disagrees with the idea that teams should move on from good coaches just because of outside pressure.

"This league has changed a lot in 21 years. When you hear conversations about the 'Mike Tomlins' of the world, the 'Matt LaFleurs' of the world, those are just two that I played for. And when I first got in the league, there wouldn't be conversations about whether those guys were on the 'hot seat,'" Rodgers said. "But the way that the league is covered now, and the way that there's snap decisions, and a validity given to the 'Twitter experts' and all the experts on TV now ... to me that's an absolute joke."

"Mike T. has had more success than damn-near everybody in the league for the last 19, 20 years. More than that, when you have the right guy, and the culture is right, you don't think about making a change. But there's a lot of pressure that comes from the outside, and obviously that sways decisions from time-to-time. But it's not how I would do things, and not how they used to be."

Aaron Rodgers, when asked about Mike Tomlin, speaks on Tomlin and on #Packers head coach Matt LaFleur after the @Steelers‚Äô playoff loss: pic.twitter.com/gTNmgQT6Qw

‚Äî Jason Wilde (@jasonjwilde) January 13, 2026

Rodgers was then asked another Tomlin-related question after that, and he didn't respond well.

"I‚Äôve talked extensively about how I feel about Mike. And I just¬†did in that f****** answer. Thanks," Rodgers said before walking away from the podium.

After giving a lengthy answer in support of Mike Tomlin, Aaron Rodgers was asked another Tomlin question‚Ä¶

‚ÄúI‚Äôve talked extensively about how I feel about Mike ‚Ä¶ and I just did in that fu**ing answer.‚Äù

And bye. ‚úåÔ∏è pic.twitter.com/u7hIwzWuea

‚Äî Ari Meirov (@MySportsUpdate) January 13, 2026

Texans defense stifles Aaron Rodgers, Steelers in wild-card win

Will Mike Tomlin, Steelers part ways after another first-round playoff exit?

How Steelers failed to take advantage of C.J. Stroud turnovers

title: Luka Doncic scores 42 points, but poor defense dooms Lakers in loss to Kings
description: A 42-point effort from Luka Doncic isn't enough for the Lakers to overcome Sacramento's 59% shooting and 17 three-pointers in 124-112 a loss.
fullText:
Lakers coach JJ Redick was asked before Monday's game against the Sacramento Kings how he could ensure his players wouldn't underestimate a nine-win team.

‚ÄúWe don't look at any game as a walkover,‚Äù Redick said.

Then the Kings walked all over the Lakers, taking a 20-point lead in the third quarter before winning 124-112 at Golden 1 Center.

Luka Doncic did his best to keep the Lakers in the game, scoring 42 points and collecting eight assists and seven rebounds. But he scored just two points in the fourth quarter and looked slower after having his left thigh wrapped at the end of the third quarter.

The Lakers got to within seven points in the fourth, but the Kings pulled away. DeMar DeRozan scored 32 points and Russell Westbrook finished with 22 points and seven assists for the Kings (10-30), who shot 59% from the field (48-82) and made 17 three-pointers.

LeBron James, who scored 22 points, wore a patch on his jersey commemorating his unprecedented 23rd NBA season in the city where he played his first NBA game. It features a silhouette of his pregame chalk toss and three colored stripes that represents the three franchises he has played on ‚Äî the Lakers, Cavaliers and Heat.

He will wear the patch for the remainder of the season. After each game, the patch will be removed from his jersey, dated and shipped to a Topps‚Äô production facility to be authenticated and inserted into a pack of trading cards.

The Lakers (23-14) looked strong from the onset when Deandre Ayton won the jump ball and eventually threw a lob pass to James for a 2-0 Lakers lead, a play that has become something the Lakers have used several times to start a game.

James hit his first four shots and the Lakers took an 8-2 lead before everything started to crumble.

They were behind 59-43 late in the second quarter. They couldn‚Äôt stop Malik Monk, who had 18 points off the bench on six-for-eight shooting, including five for six from three-point range. Monk finished with 26 points.

After the hot start, James finished the first half going five for 12 from the field for 12 points. He finished the game shooting eight for 17.

The Lakers will play the Atlanta Hawks on Tuesday night at Crypto.com Arena. When the Lakers played a back-to-back game last week, James sat out the second game. Will he do the same Tuesday?

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll see how he feels in the morning,‚Äù Redick said.

Perhaps Rui Hachimura will make his return from right calf soreness. He was available to play Monday, but he sat out his seventh consecutive game.

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

title: Lakers player grades: L.A. gets steamrolled by Kings
description: The Lakers defense went from on the mend to very weak on Monday, and it resulted in an unacceptable loss to the Kings.
fullText:
After back-to-back losses to the San Antonio Spurs and Milwaukee Bucks, the Los Angeles Lakers looked to get back in the win column when they faced the struggling Sacramento Kings on Monday. Sacramento had just ended a seven-game losing streak, and it came into this game with a 9-30 record, which was the second-worst record in the Western Conference.

The Lakers got out to an early 19-10 lead thanks to some active defense and several fast-break scores. But they went cold for an extended stretch soon afterward and fell behind by as many as 16 points in the second quarter. An 11-2 Lakers run brought them to within 61-54 at halftime, but Sacramento boosted its lead to 20 minutes later, and the Lakers were never able to mount a serious rally, resulting in a 124-112 loss for them.

Even without three-time All-Star center Domantas Sabonis, who has a meniscus injury, the Kings were able to steamroll L.A. with some precise execution and offense. They shot 58.5% from the field and an unbelievable 65.4% from 3-point range, and they caught Los Angeles slow on its defensive rotations to 3-point shooters. Guard Malik Monk, a former Laker, burned his old team with 26 points and seven treys off the bench. Even Russell Westbrook, another former Laker, hit four of his eight attempts from downtown.

Los Angeles' defense wasn't the only problem. While it shot 48.8% overall, it was just 8-of-36 from beyond the arc and had a pronounced lack of offensive balance. Only four of its players hit double figures in scoring, and only two of its men had more than 13 points.

The Lakers are now on a three-game losing streak, and with a 23-14 record, they're still in fifth place in the Western Conference, but they're in a virtual tie with the sixth-place Phoenix Suns. They're only half a game ahead of the Houston Rockets, who are in seventh place, and they will return home to face the Atlanta Hawks on Tuesday.

Smart had some moments where he played effective defense, but he was a liability on the other end of the court. He missed all five of his shot attempts and scored one point, to go along with two rebounds, two assists and two steals in 31 minutes.

LaRavia was another player who contributed next to nothing offensively. He missed six of his seven shot attempts and went 0-of-5 from 3-point range, and he ended up with two points, two rebounds, three assists and one steal in 31 minutes.

Ayton had nine rebounds in the first half and 13 for the game, including five on the offensive glass, and he went 4-of-7 from the field. While he got eight free throw attempts, which is a high and unusual amount for him, he made just five of them, which limited him to 13 points in 27 minutes. Ayton also contributed one assist and two blocks, but L.A. could've used a little more scoring from him.

James got off to a hot start in this game with several transition buckets and 10 points overall in the first quarter. But he faded afterward and finished with an anemic 22 points on 8-of-17 field-goal shooting while missing all five of his 3-point tries. He also had four rebounds, three assists and one steal in 33 minutes.

Doncic, at times, almost single-handedly prevented L.A. from falling completely out of this contest early on. He had 26 first-half points on 10-of-14 shooting, with 15 of them coming in bunches during the second quarter. He tried to put his team on his back and carry it toward a comeback, but he didn't receive nearly enough help.

In all, he scored 42 points and went 16-of-25 from the field, although he was 2-of-9 from downtown. Doncic also helped out with seven rebounds, eight assists and four steals.

This was a relatively quiet night for Vanderbilt. In 26 minutes, he got four rebounds, but he missed his three field-goal attempts and went scoreless.

Vincent went 3-of-6 overall and 3-of-5 from downtown, giving him nine points, plus one assist and one steal, in 18 minutes. He hit two of his treys early in the fourth quarter to try to jump-start a Lakers comeback, but to no avail.

Hayes was fairly aggressive and energetic throughout this contest. He got 19 minutes of playing time, and he made five of his six shot attempts to finish with 12 points, while also grabbing four offensive rebounds and five total boards.

Knecht got onto the court for 13 minutes and hit two of his six shot attempts, including one 3-pointer. He finished with five points, two rebounds and one assist.

The younger James, Kleber and Smith each played only during the final 1:53 of this game. The younger James hit both of his shot attempts and scored six points, while Kleber and Smith went scoreless.

This article originally appeared on LeBron Wire: Lakers player grades: L.A. gets steamrolled by Kings

title: Pentagon bought device through undercover operation some investigators suspect is linked to Havana Syndrome
description: The Defense Department has spent more than a year testing a device purchased in an undercover operation that some investigators think could be the cause of a series of mysterious ailments impacting spies, diplomats and troops that are colloquially known as Havana Syndrome, according to four sources briefed on the matter.
fullText:
The Defense Department has spent more than a year testing a device purchased in an undercover operation that some investigators think could be the cause of a series of mysterious ailments impacting US spies, diplomats and troops that are colloquially known as Havana Syndrome, according to four sources briefed on the matter.

A division of the Department of Homeland Security, Homeland Security Investigations, purchased the device for millions of dollars in the waning days of the Biden administration, using funding provided by the Defense Department, according to two of the sources. Officials paid ‚Äúeight figures‚Äù for the device, these people said, declining to offer a more specific number.

The device is still being studied and there is ongoing debate ‚Äî and in some quarters of government, skepticism ‚Äî over its link to the roughly dozens of anomalous health incidents that remain officially unexplained.

CNN has asked the Pentagon, HSI and the DHS for comment. The CIA declined to comment.

The device acquired by HSI produces pulsed radio waves, one of the sources said, which some officials and academics have speculated for years could be the cause of the incidents. Although the device is not entirely Russian in origin, it contains Russian components, this person added.

Officials have long struggled to understand how a device powerful enough to cause the kind of damage some victims have reported could be made portable; that remains a core question, according to one of the sources briefed on the device. The device could fit in a backpack, this person said.

The acquisition of the device has reignited a painful and contentious debate within the US government about Havana Syndrome, known officially as ‚Äúanomalous health episodes.‚Äù

The mysterious illness first emerged in late 2016, when a cluster of US diplomats stationed in the Cuban capital of Havana began reporting symptoms consistent with head trauma, including vertigo and extreme headaches. In subsequent years, there have been cases reported around the world.

In the subsequent decade the intelligence community and the Defense Department have sought to understand if those officials were the victims of some kind of directed energy attack by a foreign government ‚Äî with senior intelligence officials saying publicly that there wasn‚Äôt enough evidence to support that conclusion and victims arguing that the US government has gaslit them and ignored important evidence that Russia was attacking American government officials.

Still, defense officials considered their findings serious enough that they briefed the House and Senate Intelligence Committees late last year, including reference to the acquired device and its testing.

One key concern now for some officials is that if the technology proves viable it may have proliferated, several of the sources said, meaning that more than one country could now have access to a device that may be capable of causing career-ending injuries to US officials.

CNN was not able to learn where ‚Äî or from whom ‚Äî HSI purchased the device, but HSI has a history of collaboration with the Defense Department for operations that take place all over the globe. The office has broad jurisdiction to investigate crimes linked to customs violations, including investigations into the proliferation of US-controlled technology or expertise overseas.

Those investigations are ‚Äúthe single biggest collaboration point between HSI and the US military,‚Äù according to a former Homeland Security official.

For example, when the US military came across US technology in Afghanistan or Iraq that raised questions about how those components came to the region, it would turn to HSI, according to the official.

It was also not clear how the US government learned of the existence of the device in order to purchase it. Havana Syndrome ‚Äî and its cause ‚Äî have remained frustratingly opaque to both the intelligence community and the medical community.

One problem facing the medical community is that there is still not a clear definition of ‚Äúanomalous health incidents‚Äù or AHIs. Tests were done, in some cases, long after symptoms began, making it harder to understand what physically happened.

In 2022, an intelligence panel investigating the cause of AHIs said that some of the episodes could ‚Äúplausibly‚Äù have been caused by ‚Äúpulsed electromagnetic energy‚Äù emitted by an external source.

But in 2023, the intelligence community said publicly that it could not link any cases to a foreign adversary, ruling it unlikely that the unexplained illness was the result of a targeted campaign by an enemy of the US. As recently as January of 2025, the broader intelligence community assessment remained that it was very unlikely that the symptoms were caused by a foreign actor ‚Äî even as an official with the Office of the Director of National Intelligence emphasized that analysts cannot ‚Äúrule out‚Äù the possibility in some small number of cases.

That stance has long incensed victims, many of whom believe strongly that intelligence exists offering black-and-white evidence that Russia is behind their symptoms, some of which have been severe enough to force retirement.

Some current and former CIA officers have raised concerns that the agency soft-pedaled its investigation, CNN has previously reported.

The acquisition of the device has been treated by some victims as potential vindication.

‚ÄúIf the [US government] has indeed uncovered such devices, then the CIA owes all the victims a f**king major and public apology for how we have been treated as pariahs,‚Äù Marc Polymeropoulos, one of the first CIA officers to go public with injuries he says he sustained in an attack in Moscow in 2017, said in a statement to CNN.

CNN‚Äôs Kylie Atwood contributed to this story.

title: Judge rejects lawyer's disputed bid to join ex-Venezuelan President Nicol√°s Maduro‚Äôs defense team
description: A federal judge on Monday nixed a former high-ranking Justice Department official‚Äôs attempt to join the team defending ex-Venezuelan President Nicol√°s Maduro‚Äôs defense team, ruling that lawyer Bruce Fein had ‚Äúno legal basis" to do so.  Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein had initially approved Fein‚Äôs application to join Maduro‚Äôs drug trafficking case but reversed course after the deposed leader‚Äôs actual lawyer, Barry Pollack, objected to his involvement.  Fein, an associate deputy attorney general during Ronald Reagan‚Äôs presidency, claimed in court papers that ‚Äúindividuals credibly situated‚Äù within Maduro‚Äôs inner circle or family had sought out his assistance.
fullText:
NEW YORK (AP) ‚Äî A federal judge on Monday nixed a former high-ranking Justice Department official‚Äôs attempt to join the team defending ex-Venezuelan President Nicol√°s Maduro‚Äôs defense team, ruling that lawyer Bruce Fein had ‚Äúno legal basis" to do so.

Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein had initially approved Fein‚Äôs application to join Maduro‚Äôs drug trafficking case but reversed course after the deposed leader‚Äôs actual lawyer, Barry Pollack, objected to his involvement.

Fein, an associate deputy attorney general during Ronald Reagan‚Äôs presidency, claimed in court papers that ‚Äúindividuals credibly situated‚Äù within Maduro‚Äôs inner circle or family had sought out his assistance. Fein claimed that Maduro ‚Äúhad expressed a desire‚Äù for his ‚Äúassistance in this matter.‚Äù

But Hellerstein said in a written order that only Maduro has the authority to retain Fein as his lawyer, not unidentified individuals. He rejected Fein's request for the judge to summon Maduro to court to ask him if he would like Fein added to the defense team.

‚ÄúIf Maduro wishes to retain Fein, he has the ability to do so," Hellerstein wrote. "Fein cannot appoint himself to represent Maduro."

Messages seeking comment were left Monday for Fein and Pollack.

Pollack, a prominent Washington lawyer whose clients have included WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, was the only lawyer with Maduro at his Jan. 5 arraignment in Manhattan federal court, days after U.S. special forces seized Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, from their home in Caracas.

In court, Maduro called it a kidnapping and declared himself a prisoner of war. Pollack told Hellerstein he expected to make ‚Äúsubstantial‚Äù court filings challenging the legality of his military abduction" and invoking immunity as the head of a sovereign state.

As Fein sought to join the case, Pollack said in a court filing last week that he'd spoken with Maduro and that the ex-leader confirmed to him that he doesn't know Fein and has not communicated with him, much less retained him or authorized him to join the case.

Fein acknowledged in a written response that he'd had no contact with Maduro by telephone, video or any other direct way.

Maduro and Flores have pleaded not guilty to charges alleging he worked with drug cartels to facilitate the shipment of thousands of tons of cocaine into the U.S. They remain held without bail at a federal jail in Brooklyn and are due back in court on March 17.

title: The Texans' Offensive Keys To Beating Pittsburgh
description: The Texans' defense is good, but they will need their offense to show up and do some things as well.
fullText:
The Texans' Offensive Keys To Beating Pittsburgh originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Houston Texans are known for their defense. They have two incredible pass rushers in Will Anderson Jr. and Danielle Hunter, Azeez Al-Shaair is the solid in the middle of that defense and their secondary, led by Derek Stingley Jr. and one of the best nickelbacks in the NFL, Jalen Pitre. But as it is in every game with every team, both sides of the ball count. The Texans' offense has had moments where they have shone, moments where they have disappeared, and other times where you don‚Äôt know what is going on. Their defense is Super Bowl-worthy, but the questions remain on the offensive side of the ball, starting with the Pittsburgh. Here are some things they must do to help their offense and pull off the win against the AFC North Champion Steelers.

The Texans have been predictable at times offensively. And that has led opposing defenses to know precisely how to defend them. To change that up, the rhythm has to change as well. The Texans ought to come out and take shots against the Steelers, as they did against the Chargers in Week 17. They scored on big-time plays in the first quarter and took an early lead that they never relinquished. In the playoffs, getting an early lead is enormous and would be beneficial for the Texans, especially their defense, as it would allow their pass-rushers to pin their ears back just a little bit more. And besides, the Steelers' defense showed they can be fooled when they think they know what you are doing.

This is already going to be a challenging game for the Pittsburgh Steelers offense, so don‚Äôt give them any help. The Texans have had times where they have given up the football and helped other teams stay in the game. Texans quarterback CJ Stroud has to value the football even when pressure is coming at him. Throw the football away or take the sack as opposed to throwing the football up for grabs. That is the best way to get beaten by Pittsburgh: to put your defense in bad positions. The less you do that and the more you make Pittsburgh have to drive long distances to score, the better the Texans‚Äô chances to win the game.

The Texans' offensive line has been something to watch all year, and for the most part, that hasn't been a good thing. They have missed assignments in the run and pass game, making it difficult for the offense to move the ball. They have also had moments where they have held up more consistently. In this game, they are going to need the best their offensive line has to offer. TJ Watt and Cameron Heyward are exceptional defensive talents who can cause real problems. The better the Texans perform up front, the easier it will be to support the Texans' defense. Texans offensive line: all eyes are on you tonight.

Monday Night Football for the world to see. Can the Texans get it done, or will they falter in prime time? We shall see tonight. But we do know the Texans' offense will have some say-so in how this one goes.

title: Maye throws late TD pass and Patriots‚Äô defense roughs up Herbert, Chargers in 16-3 playoff win
description: New England held Los Angeles to 207 yards of offense and sacked Justin Herbert six times.
fullText:
Patriots coach Mike Vrabel talked to his team about being prepared to bleed as New England entered its first playoff game since the 2021 season.

Then, shortly after Milton Williams sacked the Chargers‚Äô Justin Herbert on Sunday night to secure the Patriots‚Äô first playoff victory in seven years, Williams celebrated with a head-butt of Vrabel.

It knocked the first-year coach backward and bloodied his lip.

‚ÄúThe big dogs come out in January. I think Milt took that to heart,‚Äù Vrabel said. ‚ÄúHe came over and got me pretty good. But that‚Äôs what happens.‚Äù

Drake Maye threw a touchdown pass to Hunter Henry in the fourth quarter, and New England‚Äôs defense roughed up Herbert as the Patriots beat Los Angeles 16-3 in an AFC wild-card playoff game.

PLAYOFF DUBBBBBBBB pic.twitter.com/xTUemyhs8f

‚Äî New England Patriots (@Patriots) January 12, 2026

Andy Borregales kicked three field goals for the Patriots (15-3), who hadn‚Äôt won in the postseason since their Super Bowl victory to cap the 2018 season. They‚Äôll host the winner of Monday night‚Äôs game between Pittsburgh and Houston in the divisional round.

In his playoff debut, Maye completed 17 of 29 passes for 268 yards and ran for a team-high 66 yards.

‚ÄúWe made plays when we had to do it,‚Äù Maye said.

He also threw an interception and lost a fumble, but the Chargers (11-7) couldn‚Äôt capitalize on those turnovers.

New England held Los Angeles to 207 yards of offense and sacked Herbert six times, with one of those resulting in a lost fumble that set up the Patriots‚Äô TD.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs on us, what we do. I‚Äôve been saying that all season,‚Äù Williams said. ‚ÄúWe can control the game. If we do what we need to do up front, we‚Äôre going to win.‚Äù

This is the second straight season in which the Chargers have lost in the wild-card round. Herbert finished 19 of 31 for 159 yards and was his team‚Äôs leading rusher with 57 yards as he fell to 0-3 in the playoffs.

Herbert was just over a month removed from surgery to repair a broken bone in his nonthrowing hand.

‚ÄúThere was no issue,‚Äù Herbert said. ‚ÄúI just have to do a better job holding on to the ball.‚Äù

Chargers coach Jim Harbaugh said his quarterback wasn‚Äôt 100 percent.

THIS IS GORGEOUS üéØ@DrakeMaye2 | @Hunter_Henry84 

üì∫ NBC pic.twitter.com/7TYUczWj3q

‚Äî New England Patriots (@Patriots) January 12, 2026

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a warrior. He just gives it everything he has, all the time,‚Äù Harbaugh said, acknowledging that Herbert was limited by his hand injury. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an issue, but he doesn‚Äôt flinch, like a warrior would.‚Äù

The last time the Chargers failed to score a TD in the playoffs was their 21-12 AFC championship game loss to the Patriots during the 2007 season.

The Patriots drove into the red zone on their first possession of the third quarter, but the drive ended when Maye was strip-sacked by Odafe Oweh and De‚ÄôShawn Hand recovered for the Chargers.

After Los Angeles punted, Maye connected on a pass to Kayshon Boutte that went for 42 yards to set the Patriots up on the Chargers 27. But New England settled for a 39-yard field goal that stretched their lead to 9-3.

Early in the fourth quarter, Maye used a 16-yard pass to Boutte and a 13-yard burst by Rhamondre Stevenson to set up his precise 28-yard TD toss to Henry that put the Patriots in front 16-3.

GET ON THAT!!!!!!

üì∫ NBC pic.twitter.com/jRUgddmwbj

‚Äî New England Patriots (@Patriots) January 12, 2026

The Chargers picked up back-to-back first downs to open their ensuing drive. But when Herbert dropped back to pass on the next play, linebacker K‚ÄôLavon Chaisson strip-sacked him and fell on loose ball.

Los Angeles had one final possession, but it ended with Herbert getting sacked by Williams on fourth down.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs playoff football. It‚Äôs going to get ugly. It‚Äôs going to get nasty. But you‚Äôve got to keep going,‚Äù Williams said.

The opening quarter had lots of action, but it took until early in the second quarter for the Patriots to end a scoreless stalemate.

With New England pinned inside its own 10 after a Chargers punt, Maye had a pass intended for Austin Hooper tipped by Teair Tart and intercepted by Daiyan Henley.

Los Angeles started with the ball on the Patriots 10 but was stopped on fourth-and-2 when Herbert misfired a pass to Keenan Allen.

The Patriots took over and got some breathing room via a 48-yard catch-and-run by Stevenson.

Thirteen plays and a fourth-down conversion later, the drive ended with Borregales‚Äô 23-yard field goal.

Patriots: CB Carlton Davis left in the first half with a toe injury but returned. ... CB Christian Gonzalez left in the second half with a head injury.

Patriots: Host either Houston or Pittsburgh next Sunday.
